   Assessment and Plan
   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, ? DM, depression who presents
   with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, possible melena 1 week ago,
   breast pain and a rash, broken ribs. Respiratory failure and sepsis
   primary issues at present.
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. Repeat blood
   cultures from [**1-16**] NGTD of Strep. Pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin (renally dosed), Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped
   Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently on
   norepi and vasopressin), CVP > 12, UO>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will Identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Will pull central line
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. Episodes of desaturation to high 80s
   overnight. Unclear etiology; CXR unremarkable. Likely secondary to
   volume overload (+16L length of stay) associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely related with underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will defer thoracentesis at this time given
   coagulopathy. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate need for
   fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Lasix 40mg [**Hospital1 **] goal -1L
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Blood Per OG Tube
   Resolving. Likely related with gastritis, stress ulcer, varices
   (previous varices banded in [**2139-6-23**]). No EGD indicated per
   hepatology given oozing and will correct primary coagulopathy.
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - q8 hour Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - PPI IV BID
   - Goal platelets > 30, INR < 2, Hct > 25
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone and Propofol. Patient
   unresponsive to voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic
   component or if related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given
   poor liver function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic
   encephalopathy. Given fungemia, considering cryptococcal meningitis or
   other causes.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Follow up methadone clinic
   - Maintain her on 20 mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, replete free water; OG tube in;
   currently NPO as holding tube feeds for high residuals
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots when able; No prophylaxis at this time given
   elevated INR and also ongoing coagulopathy

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion:
	* ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome) due to bilateral infiltrates and decreased P:F ratio.
	* Respiratory acidosis and primary metabolic alkalosis.
	* Unclear etiology, but likely related to underlying pneumonia/infection.
2. Fungemia:
	* Yeast infection, likely Candida spp., as evidenced by blood cultures.
	* Potential for dissemination to other organs, such as the brain or kidneys.
	* May require antifungal therapy, such as Micafungin.
3. Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia:
	* Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin, likely due to cholestasis or liver injury.
	* May require further evaluation and management, such as liver function tests and imaging.
4. Pancytopenia:
	* Low white blood cell, red blood cell, and platelet counts, likely due to underlying liver disease or bone marrow suppression.
	* May require blood product transfusions and bone marrow stimulation.
5. Altered Mental Status:
	* Encephalopathy, potentially due to hypoxia, sepsis, or liver failure.
	* May require further evaluation and management, such as EEG, imaging, and neurology consultation.
6. Abdominal Rash:
	* Vesicular rash, likely due to viral or bacterial infection.
	* May require further evaluation and management, such as cultures and dermatology consultation.
7. Opioid Dependence:
	* Patient is dependent on methadone, which may require ongoing management and monitoring.
8. DM/Hypoglycemia:
	* Patient has a history of hypoglycemic events and elevated insulin and C-peptide levels.
	* May require further evaluation and management, such as insulin therapy and glucose monitoring.
9. Acute Kidney Injury:
	* Patient has acute kidney injury, likely due to sepsis and fluid overload.
	* May require further evaluation and management, such as nephrology consultation and fluid management.

The patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing monitoring and management to address these potential complications. The healthcare team should continue to assess the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status, as well as their liver and kidney function, to ensure that they receive appropriate care and treatment.

   Assessment and Plan
   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, ? DM, depression who presents
   with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, possible melena 1 week ago,
   breast pain and a rash, broken ribs. Respiratory failure and sepsis
   primary issues at present.
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. Repeat blood
   cultures from [**1-16**] NGTD of Strep. Pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin, Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently on
   norepi and vasopressin), CVP > 12, UO>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will Identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Discuss on rounds re: pull line
   .
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. Episodes of desaturation to high 80s
   overnight. Unclear etiology; CXR unremarkable. Likely secondary to
   volume overload (+16L length of stay) associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely related with underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will defer thoracentesis at this time given
   coagulopathy. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate need for
   fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Continue Lasix gtt goal -1L
   # Blood Per OG Tube
   Resolving. Likely related with gastritis, stress ulcer, varices
   (previous varices banded in [**2139-6-23**]). No EGD indicated per
   hepatology given oozing and will correct primary coagulopathy.
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - q8 hour Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - PPI IV BID
   - Goal platelets > 50, INR < 2, Hct > 25
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone and Propofol. Patient
   unresponsive to voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic
   component or if related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given
   poor liver function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Follow up methadone clinic
   - Maintain her on 20 mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, OG tube in; currently NPO as
   holding tube feeds for high residuals
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots when able; No prophylaxis at this time given
   elevated INR and also ongoing coagulopathy
   # Access:

   Multi Lumen central line placed [**1-11**]; will need to remove given
   fungemia

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that can lead to organ failure and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has developed respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and acidosis if not managed properly.
3. Fungemia: The patient has been diagnosed with fungemia, which is a serious infection that can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient has developed transaminitis and hyperbilirubinemia, which can lead to liver dysfunction and failure if not managed properly.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient has developed altered mental status, which can lead to confusion, disorientation, and coma if not managed properly.
6. Pancytopenia: The patient has developed pancytopenia, which can lead to bleeding, infection, and organ failure if not managed properly.
7. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient has developed acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
8. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient has developed abdominal compartment syndrome, which can lead to organ failure and death if not managed properly.
9. Hypoglycemia: The patient has developed hypoglycemia, which can lead to coma, seizures, and death if not managed properly.
10. Opioid Dependence: The patient has developed opioid dependence, which can lead to addiction, overdose, and death if not managed properly.

The patient's medical history and current condition suggest that they are at high risk for these complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat them promptly and effectively.

   Assessment and Plan
   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, ? DM, depression who presents
   with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, possible melena 1 week ago,
   breast pain and a rash, broken ribs. Respiratory failure and sepsis
   primary issues at present.
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. Repeat blood
   cultures from [**1-16**] NGTD of Strep. Pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin, Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently on
   norepi and vasopressin), CVP > 12, UO>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will Identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Discuss on rounds re: pull line
   .
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. Episodes of desaturation to high 80s
   overnight. Unclear etiology; CXR unremarkable. Likely secondary to
   volume overload (+16L length of stay) associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely related with underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will defer thoracentesis at this time given
   coagulopathy. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate need for
   fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Continue Lasix gtt goal -1L
   # Blood Per OG Tube
   Resolving. Likely related with gastritis, stress ulcer, varices
   (previous varices banded in [**2139-6-23**]). No EGD indicated per
   hepatology given oozing and will correct primary coagulopathy.
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - q8 hour Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - PPI IV BID
   - Goal platelets > 50, INR < 2, Hct > 25
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone and Propofol. Patient
   unresponsive to voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic
   component or if related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given
   poor liver function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Follow up methadone clinic
   - Maintain her on 20 mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, OG tube in; currently NPO as
   holding tube feeds for high residuals
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots when able; No prophylaxis at this time given
   elevated INR and also ongoing coagulopathy

3. ARDS: The patient's bilateral infiltrates and decreased P:F ratio suggest that the patient may have acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
4. Fungemia: The patient has fungemia, which is likely related to the presence of yeast in the blood culture. The patient's fungemia may be a sign of a more widespread fungal infection.
5. Transaminitis: The patient has transaminitis, which is likely related to the underlying liver disease and the presence of yeast in the blood culture.
6. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's bilirubin levels are elevated, which is likely related to the underlying liver disease and the presence of yeast in the blood culture.
7. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal distension and increasing intracranial pressure suggest that the patient may be at risk for abdominal compartment syndrome.
8. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia is likely related to the underlying liver disease and the presence of yeast in the blood culture.
9. Opioid dependence: The patient has a history of opioid dependence, and the use of methadone to manage pain may exacerbate this condition.
10. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely related to the underlying liver disease and the presence of yeast in the blood culture.

In terms of the patient's overall condition, the patient is at high risk for further complications and may require ongoing intensive care and monitoring. The patient's respiratory status is also compromised, and the patient may require ongoing mechanical ventilation to support respiration.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient's chief complaint is not specified, but the note highlights several significant findings and interventions.

The patient's laboratory results show abnormal values, including:

* Elevated white blood cell count (34 K/uL)
* Low hemoglobin level (8.9 g/dL)
* Elevated bilirubin level (178 mg/dL)
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT 79, AST 226)
* Elevated lactate level (3.4 mmol/L)
* Low albumin level (2.9 g/dL)
* Elevated LDH level (804 IU/L)

The patient's imaging studies, including a CT Torso, reveal:

* Moderate right pleural effusion
* Abdominal ascites
* Cirrhotic liver with splenomegaly and splenic varices
* Pan colonic wall thickening suggestive of pancolitis
* Bilateral rib fractures
* Total body anasarca

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including:

* Propofol
* Furosemide (Lasix)
* Pantoprazole (Protonix)
* Methadone Hydrochloride
* Micafungin

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
* Vt (Set): 400 mL
* Vt (Spontaneous): 518 mL
* PS: 12 cmH2O
* RR (Set): 25
* RR (Spontaneous): 0
* PEEP: 15 cmH2O
* FiO2: 80%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Intubated and sedated
* Sclera icteric
* Intubated and dried blood on lips
* Obese with distended and moderately tense abdomen
* Diminished bowel sounds
* Rash on LLQ and diffuse petechial rash on chest
* Nectrotic region on left breast and enlarged bullae
* Vesicles on stomach resolving
* Chronic venous stasis changes on lower extremities

The patient's neurologic examination is limited due to sedation, but the pupils are reactive.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to the patient's low white blood cell count and elevated lactate level
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's bilateral lung opacities and need for mechanical ventilation
* Hepatic failure due to the patient's cirrhosis and elevated liver enzymes
* Renal failure due to the patient's low albumin level and elevated creatinine level
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to the patient's pancolitis and portal hypertension
* Venous thromboembolism (VTE) due to the patient's immobility and risk factors
* Infection due to the patient's immunocompromised state and presence of Candida in the blood culture

Based on the patient's complex medical condition and laboratory results, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory values, and imaging studies to prevent potential complications and optimize treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old woman with Child's C cirrhosis in the MICU with septic shock, persistently elevated lactate, respiratory failure with severe hypoxemia, and a bullous abdominal rash. She has been improving hemodynamically but continues to have severe hypoxemia. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, antifungals, and vasopressors, and is receiving mechanical ventilation and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may lead to further organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver failure, and cardiovascular collapse.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
4. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction, ascites, and encephalopathy.
5. Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS): The patient's TSS may lead to further organ dysfunction, including cardiovascular collapse, respiratory failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
7. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and seizures.
8. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to delirium, agitation, and increased risk of falls and injury.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of her septic shock, respiratory failure, and cirrhosis. The patient's antibiotic and antifungal therapy should be continued and adjusted as necessary. Further evaluation and management of her coagulopathy, electrolyte and fluid disorder, and altered mental status are also necessary.

   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, ? DM, depression who presents
   with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, possible melena 1 week ago,
   breast pain and a rash, broken ribs. Respiratory failure and sepsis
   primary issues at present.
   # GIB/BRBPR
   Episode this AM with approximately 500cc BRBPR. Likely related with
   coagulopathy with component of variceal bleed.
   - Maintain access
   - IVF bolus, albumin, pRBCs, FFP, platelets goal Hct > 25, INR < 2,
   platelets > 30
   - GI/hepatology consult
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **] consider drip
   - Octreotide consider drip
   - q6 hour Hct, INR, platelets
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. Repeat blood
   cultures from [**1-16**] NGTD of Strep. Pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin (renally dosed), Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped
   Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently on
   norepi and vasopressin), CVP > 12, UO>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date. Central line removed
   [**2141-1-19**] given fungemia.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. Episodes of desaturation to high 80s
   overnight. Unclear etiology; CXR unremarkable. Likely secondary to
   volume overload (+16L length of stay) associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely related with underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will defer thoracentesis at this time given
   coagulopathy. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate need for
   fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Consider lasix when BPs stable
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone and Propofol. Patient
   unresponsive to voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic
   component or if related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given
   poor liver function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic
   encephalopathy. Given fungemia, considering cryptococcal meningitis or
   other causes. Cryptococcal serology negative.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Maintain her on 15mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, replete free water; OG tube in;
   currently NPO as holding tube feeds for high residuals
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots when able; No prophylaxis at this time given
   elevated INR and also ongoing coagulopathy

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, COPD, and possible diabetes, who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure, sepsis, and fungemia.

The patient has a significant number of medical issues, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has a high risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient has a positive blood culture for Streptococcus pneumoniae and is receiving antibiotics.
3. Fungemia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast and is receiving antifungal medication.
4. Abdominal pain: The patient has a history of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which may be related to her cirrhosis or other underlying conditions.
5. Altered mental status: The patient has a altered mental status and is receiving sedation and analgesia.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which may be related to her liver disease or other underlying conditions.
7. Pancytopenia: The patient has a low white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin level.
8. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a history of acute kidney injury and is receiving fluids and medications to support kidney function.
9. Hypoglycemia: The patient has a history of hypoglycemic events and is receiving insulin and other medications to manage her blood sugar levels.

The patient's current medical condition is unstable, and she requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The potential medical complications that can arise from her current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may develop further respiratory failure, which could lead to the need for more aggressive ventilation or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient may develop further sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
3. Fungemia: The patient may develop further fungemia, which could lead to the need for more aggressive antifungal therapy or even surgery.
4. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient may develop abdominal compartment syndrome, which could lead to organ failure and death.
5. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient may develop hepatic encephalopathy, which could lead to altered mental status and even coma.
6. Acute kidney injury: The patient may develop further acute kidney injury, which could lead to the need for dialysis or even kidney transplantation.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient may develop further hypoglycemic events, which could lead to brain damage or even death.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues that require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The potential medical complications that can arise from her current condition are significant, and she requires careful management and monitoring to prevent these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, ? DM, depression who presents
   with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, possible melena 1 week ago,
   breast pain and a rash, broken ribs. Respiratory failure and sepsis
   primary issues at present.
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. Repeat blood
   cultures from [**1-16**] NGTD of Strep. Pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin (renally dosed), Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped
   Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently on
   norepi and vasopressin), CVP > 12, UO>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will Identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date. Central line removed
   [**2141-1-19**] given fungemia.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. Episodes of desaturation to high 80s
   overnight. Unclear etiology; CXR unremarkable. Likely secondary to
   volume overload (+16L length of stay) associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely related with underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will defer thoracentesis at this time given
   coagulopathy. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate need for
   fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Lasix 40mg [**Hospital1 **] goal -1L
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Blood Per OG Tube
   Resolving. Likely related with gastritis, stress ulcer, varices
   (previous varices banded in [**2139-6-23**]). No EGD indicated per
   hepatology given oozing and will correct primary coagulopathy.
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - q8 hour Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - PPI IV BID
   - Goal platelets > 30, INR < 2, Hct > 25
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone and Propofol. Patient
   unresponsive to voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic
   component or if related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given
   poor liver function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic
   encephalopathy. Given fungemia, considering cryptococcal meningitis or
   other causes. Cryptococcal serology negative.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Maintain her on 15mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, replete free water; OG tube in;
   currently NPO as holding tube feeds for high residuals
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots when able; No prophylaxis at this time given
   elevated INR and also ongoing coagulopathy
   # Access:
   - Double Lumen midline placed [**1-18**]; will need to be removed [**1-21**]
   - Arterial Line placed [**1-12**]; will need to remove given fungemia
   - 20 Gauge placed [**1-13**]
   # Communication: Patient; patient
s sister [**Name (NI) 142**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10512**]);
   [**Doctor First Name 2778**] is [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 142**]
[**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] (cell [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10591**]). Patient
s family may come
   in

s HCP)

   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, ? DM, depression who presents
   with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, possible melena 1 week ago,
   breast pain and a rash, broken ribs. Respiratory failure and sepsis
   primary issues at present.
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. Repeat blood
   cultures from [**1-16**] NGTD of Strep. Pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin (renally dosed), Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped
   Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently on
   norepi and vasopressin), CVP > 12, UO>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will Identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date. Central line removed
   [**2141-1-19**] given fungemia.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. Episodes of desaturation to high 80s
   overnight. Unclear etiology; CXR unremarkable. Likely secondary to
   volume overload (+16L length of stay) associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely related with underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will defer thoracentesis at this time given
   coagulopathy. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate need for
   fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Lasix 40mg [**Hospital1 **] goal -1L
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Blood Per OG Tube
   Resolving. Likely related with gastritis, stress ulcer, varices
   (previous varices banded in [**2139-6-23**]). No EGD indicated per
   hepatology given oozing and will correct primary coagulopathy.
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - q8 hour Hct
   - Guaiac stools
   - PPI IV BID
   - Goal platelets > 30, INR < 2, Hct > 25
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone and Propofol. Patient
   unresponsive to voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic
   component or if related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given
   poor liver function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic
   encephalopathy. Given fungemia, considering cryptococcal meningitis or
   other causes. Cryptococcal serology negative.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Maintain her on 15mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, replete free water; OG tube in;
   currently NPO as holding tube feeds for high residuals
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots when able; No prophylaxis at this time given
   elevated INR and also ongoing coagulopathy
   # Access:
   - Double Lumen midline placed [**1-18**]; will need to be removed [**1-21**]
   - Arterial Line placed [**1-12**]; will need to remove given fungemia
   - 20 Gauge placed [**1-13**]

s sister [**Name (NI) 142**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10512**]);

s family may come

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old female with cirrhosis, COPD, and possible diabetes, who presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and a rash. She has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure, sepsis, and fungemia.

The patient has a complex medical history, including liver disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and possible diabetes. She has also had a history of trauma, including rib fractures and possible neck trauma.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 168, indicating moderate respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient has a positive blood culture for Streptococcus pneumoniae and is receiving antibiotics.
* Fungemia: The patient has a positive blood culture for yeast and is receiving antifungal medication.
* Abdominal pain: The patient has a history of abdominal pain and nausea, and has a positive stool culture for Clostridium difficile toxin A and B.
* Rash: The patient has a rash on her abdomen, which is improving with treatment.
* Altered mental status: The patient is sedated and has a altered mental status, which is likely due to her underlying medical conditions and medications.
* Pancytopenia: The patient has a low white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin level.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient has a elevated creatinine level and is receiving dialysis.

The patient's medical team is considering the following potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to her positive blood culture and antibiotic therapy.
* Fungemia: The patient is at risk for developing fungemia due to her positive blood culture and antifungal medication.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for developing respiratory failure due to her underlying COPD and possible pneumonia.
* Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient is at risk for developing abdominal compartment syndrome due to her abdominal distension and possible bowel obstruction.
* Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient is at risk for developing hepatic encephalopathy due to her underlying liver disease and possible medication overdose.

The patient's medical team is also considering the following potential medical interventions:

* Antibiotics: The patient is receiving antibiotics for her positive blood culture and possible pneumonia.
* Antifungal medication: The patient is receiving antifungal medication for her positive blood culture and possible fungemia.
* Dialysis: The patient is receiving dialysis for her acute kidney injury.
* Vasopressors: The patient is receiving vasopressors for her sepsis and possible hypotension.
* Pain management: The patient is receiving pain management medication for her abdominal pain and possible trauma.

Overall, the patient's medical team is closely monitoring her condition and is considering the potential medical complications and interventions to optimize her care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old woman with Child's C cirrhosis in the MICU with septic shock, respiratory failure, and severe hypoxemia. The patient has a bullous abdominal rash and GPCs growing from the blood.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.9°C (102°F)
* Heart rate: 116 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 143/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.9 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 32 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Total bilirubin: 26 μmol/L
* Lactic acid: 3.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.8 g/dL
* LDH: 861 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 3.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Septic shock/S. pneumonia bacteremia/fungemia
* Respiratory failure with severe hypoxemia
* GI bleed/blood loss anemia
* Acute renal failure
* Cirrhosis
* Altered mental status
* Impaired skin integrity
* Pain control
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Toxic shock syndrome (TSS)
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous vancomycin for S. pneumonia bacteremia
* Continuous micafungin for fungemia
* Packed red blood cells and IV fluids for blood loss anemia
* Fresh frozen plasma and platelets for coagulopathy
* Hepatology team aware of patient's condition
* Restarting lactulose for possible hepatic encephalopathy
* Ongoing respiratory support with high FIO2
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further deterioration of respiratory status
* Development of acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease
* Progression of septic shock
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Worsening of cirrhosis and liver failure
* Development of multi-organ failure
* Increased risk of infection due to immunosuppression
* Potential for TSS or ARDS to worsen

The patient's current condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications and improve her outcomes.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she is at risk for further deterioration.
* Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is ongoing, and she is at risk for further organ dysfunction.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver function is deteriorating, and she is at risk for further liver damage.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is ongoing, and she is at risk for further kidney damage.
* Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is ongoing, and she is at risk for further bleeding complications.
* Infectious complications: The patient's septic shock is ongoing, and she is at risk for further infectious complications.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old woman with Child's C cirrhosis in the MICU with septic shock, persistently elevated lactate, respiratory failure, and severe hypoxemia. She has a bullous abdominal rash and GPCs growing from the blood.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Septic shock/S. pneumo bacteremia/fungemia: The patient is being treated with vancomycin, micafungin, and flagyl.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has ongoing bilateral pneumonia and bibasilar collapse, and is on a high FIO2.
3. GI bleed/Blood loss anemia: The patient has received pRBCs, IVF, and FFP, and platelets are being transfused.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is decreasing.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient's bilirubin level is increasing, and she has developed esophageal and gastric varices.
6. Altered mental status: The patient is unable to follow simple commands and responds only to painful stimuli.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular instability.
* Respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* GI bleeding, including rebleeding and further blood loss anemia.
* Acute kidney injury, including worsening renal failure and potential need for dialysis.
* Cirrhosis-related complications, including worsening liver function, portal hypertension, and potential bleeding from esophageal and gastric varices.
* Altered mental status, including worsening encephalopathy and potential need for intubation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's code status has been changed to DNR/DNI, and her prognosis is poor at this point, particularly if she rebleeds.

   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date. Central line removed
   [**2141-1-19**] given fungemia.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation

   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input

   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,

   # Goals of Care

   Patient currently intubated x 10 days. Will need to discuss PEG, trach

   - Family meeting

   Likely secondary to ongoing fluid shifts, component of renal failure.
   - Replete free water, D5W

   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone. Patient unresponsive to
   voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic component or if

   # Pancytopenia

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 40-year-old female with cirrhosis, COPD, depression, and a history of Hepatitis C. She presented with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, melena, breast pain, and a rash. She has developed respiratory failure, DIC, sepsis, hepatic failure, and altered mental status. The patient has been intubated for 10 days and is currently on mechanical ventilation. She has been diagnosed with fungemia, sepsis, and respiratory failure, and is at risk for further complications.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Re-bleeding:** The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and has undergone variceal banding. There is a high likelihood of re-bleeding, which could lead to further complications.
2. **Sepsis:** The patient has sepsis and is at risk for further complications, including organ failure and death.
3. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient has respiratory failure and is at risk for further complications, including pneumonia, ARDS, and death.
4. **DIC:** The patient has disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and is at risk for further complications, including bleeding and organ failure.
5. **Hepatic Failure:** The patient has hepatic failure and is at risk for further complications, including encephalopathy, ascites, and death.
6. **Infections:** The patient has fungemia and sepsis, and is at risk for further infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections.
7. **Renal Failure:** The patient has acute kidney injury and is at risk for further complications, including chronic kidney disease and death.
8. **Pulmonary Embolism:** The patient has a high risk of developing a pulmonary embolism due to her immobility and respiratory failure.
9. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient has a history of COPD and is at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and heart failure.
10. **Mental Status Changes:** The patient has altered mental status and is at risk for further complications, including encephalopathy and death.

**Assessment and Plan:**

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's care team should continue to monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and adjust her treatment plan accordingly. The patient's family should be educated on her condition and treatment plan, and a code status of DNR/DNI should be respected. The patient's social work consult should be completed to address her mental health and social support needs. The patient's pain should be managed, and she should be provided with adequate nutrition and hydration. The patient's lines and tubes should be monitored and managed according to protocol. The patient's antibiotic therapy should be continued, and she should be monitored for signs of infection. The patient's liver function should be monitored, and she should be treated for any signs of liver failure.

   Assessment and Plan
   40 yo F with cirrhosis [**1-24**] hep C, COPD, depression who presents with
   abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, melena, breast pain and a rash,
   broken ribs. Respiratory failure, DIC, sepsis, hepatic failure and
   altered mental status primary issues at present.
   # GIB/BRBPR
   Episode yesterday with approximately 2.5L blood per rectum total. S/p
   EGD GI intervention with variceal banding and Dermabond. High
   likelihood of rebleed. Complicated by ongoing coagulopathy/DIC.
   - Maintain access
   - IVF bolus, albumin, pRBCs, FFP, platelets goal Hct > 25, INR < 2,
   platelets > 30
   - Appreciate hepatology recommendations; continue to follow their
   recommendations
   - IV PPI drip
   - Octreotide drip
   - q6 hour Hct, INR, platelets
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. No growth to date
   of multiple blood cultures since that time of Strep pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin (renally dosed), Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped
   Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently not
   on pressors), CVP > 12, UOP>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date. Central line removed
   [**2141-1-19**] given fungemia.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. CXR unremarkable consistent with
   volume overload (+16L length of stay), likely associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely component of underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate
   need for fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Lasix 20-40mg prn
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone. Patient unresponsive to
   voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic component or if
   related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given poor liver
   function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic encephalopathy. Given
   fungemia, considering cryptococcal meningitis or other causes although
   less likely as Cryptococcal serology negative.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Maintain her on 15mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, replete free water; OG
   tube/currently NPO
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots; elevated INR
   # Access:
   - Double Lumen midline placed [**1-18**]; will need to be removed [**1-21**]
   - Arterial Line placed [**1-12**]; changed over wire on [**1-20**]
   - Left IJ placed [**1-20**]
   - 18 Gauge placed [**1-20**]
   # Communication: Patient; patient
s sister [**Name (NI) 142**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10512**]);
   [**Doctor First Name 2778**] is [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 142**]
[**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] (cell [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10591**]).
   # Code:  DNR/DNI (discussed with patient
s HCP)
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care

   - IVF bolus, albumin, pRBCs, FFP, platelets goal Hct > 25, INR < 2,
   platelets > 30
   - Appreciate hepatology recommendations; continue to follow their
   recommendations
   - IV PPI drip
   - Octreotide drip
   - q6 hour Hct, INR, platelets
   # Sepsis/Strep Pneumo Bacteremia
   Strep. Pneumo in blood. Consistent with all cultures. No growth to date
   of multiple blood cultures since that time of Strep pneumo.
   - Continue Vancomycin (renally dosed), Flagyl and Meropenem (stopped
   Linezolid [**1-13**])
   - Early goal directed care; MAP > 65 with pressors prn (currently not
   on pressors), CVP > 12, UOP>30cc
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Trend blood cultures
   # Fungemia
   Two sets of blood cultures from [**1-16**] positive for yeast. Will identify
   type over next 48 hours. Negative ophtho evaluation on [**1-18**]. Will need
   repeat eye exam in 2 weeks from that date. Central line removed
   [**2141-1-19**] given fungemia.
   - Continue Micafungin until speciation
   - Trend blood cultures
   - Continue to follow ID recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Respiratory Failure/Pleural Effusion
   ABG indicates primary metabolic alkalosis which is compensated;
   concomitant respiratory acidosis. CXR unremarkable consistent with
   volume overload (+16L length of stay), likely associated with DIC
   resuscitation. Meets criteria for ARDS given decreased P: F ratio,
   bilateral infiltrates. Likely component of underlying
   pneumonia/infection. Will follow pressure, I&Os and UOP to estimate
   need for fluid, although likely significant insensible losses.
   - Continue CMV assist
   - Continue ARDSnet protocol ventilation with low tidal volume and low
   rate ventilation given fairly large empyema/ascites; brought down tidal
   volume and rate; increased FiO2. Given incomplete expiration (COPD
   contributing) reduce rate and possibly minute ventilation slightly to
   prevent auto PEEP
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Lasix 20-40mg prn
   # Transaminitis/Hyperbilirubinemia
   Stable/downtrending at this time although bilirubin continues to rise.
   Unclear etiology, but most likely related to cholestasis in the setting
   of acute illness.
   - Continue antibiotics as above
   - Monitor vesicular pressure daily for previous concern re: abdominal
   compartment syndrome
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   # Abdominal Rash
   Has continued to improve on therapy. Vesicular with PMNs only so far.
   DFA negative. Viral culture preliminary negative.
   - Continue to follow cultures
   - Re-culture rash if worse
   - Continue to follow dermatology recommendations; appreciate their
   input
   # Altered Mental Status
   Head CT without acute process. On Methadone. Patient unresponsive to
   voice but does withdrawal to pain. Uncertain if hypoxic component or if
   related to poor elimination of sedation/benzos given poor liver
   function. Ammonia not elevated; unlikely hepatic encephalopathy. Given
   fungemia, considering cryptococcal meningitis or other causes although
   less likely as Cryptococcal serology negative.
   - Continue to follow
   - Minimize sedation/benzos
   - Continue lactulose
   # Cirrhosis
   Secondary to Hep C, possible also made worse by EtOH.  Followed by
   liver clinic (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].  Hepatology evaluated patient in ED.  Her
   liver synthetic function is decreased based on INR.  T bili elevated as
   well since admission.  [**Month (only) 11**] be decompensation of already poor liver.
   MELD 29 today. Alpha-1-anti-trypsin within normal limits (checked given
   early COPD).
   - Continue to follow hepatology recommendations; appreciate their input
   - Continue lactulose
   - Hold nadalol, spironolactone at this time
   # Positive UA
   E.coli negative in blood cultures. Covered by meropenem
   # Pancytopenia
   Counts are stably low.  Likely related to hep C.  Patient reports being
   HIV negative multiple time in OMR but no HIV documented.  Given
   fungemia, will need to test with consent.
   - Discuss with patient HIV test when possible
   # Rib Fractures/Trauma
   Etiology unclear. Ecchymoses on exam (shoulder and back).  Possible
   neck trauma, unable to assess pain. Trauma was consulted in ED.
   Possible history of abuse. Nothing to do for now.
   - Pain control with fentanyl
   - Social work consult when awake
   - Obtain further history when able
   # Opioid dependence
   Continue methadone at last known dose (called [**Hospital 10552**] clinic but
   no-one on call today ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10559**]).
   - Maintain her on 15mg q8h IV (on 70 mg PO QD according to last
   discharge summary)
   # DM/Hypoglycmia
   Blood glucose normal. Hypoglycemic events and past elevated insulin and
   C-peptide, although not strikingly high. Patients Hb A1c was 5.
   Consider insulinoma and other DDx.
   -ISS (for dextrose also)
 glucagon less likely to be helpful.
   # Acute Kidney Injury
   Continues to improve with fluid.  Received and should continue to
   receive pre/post-treatment with bicarb/Mucomyst if CT with contrast.
   - Trend Cr
   - Avoid nephrotoxins, renally dose medications
   # FEN: IVF prn, replete electrolytes, replete free water; OG
   tube/currently NPO
   # Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots; elevated INR
   # Access:
   - Double Lumen midline placed [**1-18**]; will need to be removed [**1-21**]
   - Arterial Line placed [**1-12**]; changed over wire on [**1-20**]
   - Left IJ placed [**1-20**]
   - 18 Gauge placed [**1-20**]
   # Communication: Patient; patient
s sister [**Name (NI) 142**] is HCP ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 10512**]);
   [**Doctor First Name 2778**] is [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) 142**]
[**Initial (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] (cell [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10591**]).

s HCP)

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old female with cirrhosis, COPD, depression, and a history of Hepatitis C. She was admitted to the ICU with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, melena, breast pain, and a rash. She has been experiencing respiratory failure, DIC, sepsis, hepatic failure, and altered mental status. She has had multiple episodes of bleeding, including a 2.5L blood per rectum episode yesterday, which required endoscopy and variceal banding. She has also had fungemia, and her blood cultures are pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Rebleeding: The patient's history of bleeding and ongoing coagulopathy/DIC increases her risk of rebleeding.
2. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and she has had multiple episodes of bleeding, which increases her risk of developing sepsis.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and she may require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
4. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status may be related to her liver dysfunction, and she may require further evaluation and treatment for hepatic encephalopathy.
5. Fungal Infections: The patient's fungemia increases her risk of developing further fungal infections, such as pneumonia or meningitis.
6. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may worsen, and she may require further evaluation and treatment to address this issue.
7. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's abdominal distension and elevated bilirubin levels increase her risk of developing abdominal compartment syndrome.
8. Opioid Dependence: The patient's history of opioid dependence may contribute to her altered mental status and may require further evaluation and treatment.
9. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's ongoing fluid resuscitation and potential for further bleeding may increase her risk of developing acute kidney injury.
10. FEN: The patient's IVF prn and replete electrolytes may be necessary to address her fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's primary issues include respiratory failure, DIC, sepsis, hepatic failure, and altered mental status. Her bleeding has been stabilized, but she requires ongoing monitoring and treatment to prevent further bleeding. She also requires further evaluation and treatment for her fungemia, pancytopenia, and potential abdominal compartment syndrome. Her opioid dependence and history of Hepatitis C require ongoing management and treatment. Her acute kidney injury and potential for further bleeding require close monitoring and treatment.

* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 756 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 4.7 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Septic shock and bacteremia/fungemia
* Respiratory failure with ongoing bilateral pneumonia
* GI bleed and blood loss anemia
* Cirrhosis with worsening liver function
* Coagulopathy with DIC and synthetic issues
* Altered mental status potentially related to hepatic encephalopathy

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing antibiotics and antifungals for septic shock and bacteremia/fungemia
* Ongoing management of respiratory failure with high FIO2
* Transfusion of blood products to support bleeding
* Close monitoring of liver function and potential need for TIPS intervention
* Discussion of goals of care with family
* Restart of lactulose for potential hepatic encephalopathy
* Monitoring for and management of potential complications such as DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

The patient's overall condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and optimize outcomes.
